guide.introduction: With a few hardware store and household items we are going to construct our own clock that looks like a classic design piece.
guide.introduction_rendered:
With a few hardware store and household items we are going to construct our own clock that looks like a classic design piece.

Tools
  • 2 small pieces of cardboard
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Metallic silver spray paint
  • Power Drill
  • Sand paper
  • clock kit
  • retro blue paint

lines.text: Cut 2 pieces of cardboard into circles that are 3 1/2" in diameter. Hot glue them together to make them stronger, avoiding the center for when you drill later. Measure and draw 2 perpendicular lines intersecting in the center. Drill through that center mark with a piece of wood behind the cardboard for safety.
lines.text_raw: Cut 2 pieces of cardboard into circles that are 3 1/2" in diameter. Hot glue them together to make them stronger, avoiding the center for when you drill later. Measure and draw 2 perpendicular lines intersecting in the center. Drill through that center mark with a piece of wood behind the cardboard for safety.

lines.text: Paint the front and sides of your clock face. While that dries, sand, cut and spray paint 12 13" dowels.
lines.text_raw: Paint the front and sides of your clock face. While that dries, sand, cut and spray paint 12 13" dowels.

lines.text: On the back of your clock face, draw 6 equidistant lines intersecting in the center as your guide.
lines.text_raw: On the back of your clock face, draw 6 equidistant lines intersecting in the center as your guide.

lines.text: Cut away any excess material around the center hole with a utility knife so the clock can fit.
lines.text_raw: Cut away any excess material around the center hole with a utility knife so the clock can fit.

lines.text: Align both 12 o'clocks on your clock and grid before gluing the two pieces together. Be careful not to get any hot glue on the center piece.
lines.text_raw: Align both 12 o'clocks on your clock and grid before gluing the two pieces together. Be careful not to get any hot glue on the center piece.

lines.text: Add your clock hands and the top small screw to the face.
lines.text_raw: Add your clock hands and the top small screw to the face.

lines.text: Using the grid as your guide, hot glue your dowels onto the back of the clock. Using a roll of tape can stabilize the surface area for this step. A bird's eye view can help you see if the dowels align.
lines.text_raw: Using the grid as your guide, hot glue your dowels onto the back of the clock. Using a roll of tape can stabilize the surface area for this step. A bird's eye view can help you see if the dowels align.

lines.text: Add a screw to the perfect spot and hang your atomic age clock.
lines.text_raw: Add a screw to the perfect spot and hang your atomic age clock.

guide.summary: Mid-century modern is such a gorgeous era and is permeating the design scene.
